Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Selective Catalytic Conversion of Syngas-Derived Dimethyl Oxalate to Ethylene Glycol: Mechanistic Insights from In-Situ Surface Vibrational Spectroscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1510157
Williams, Christopher T

The proposed work will examine the reactions involved in producing ethylene glycol (EG) - an important industrial chemical - from synthesis gas via catalytic dehydrogenation reactions of dialkyl oxalate intermediates. This opens the door to EG production from non-conventional sources such as coal, natural gas, and biomass instead of the conventional process based on ethylene oxide produced from petroleum resources. Although the technology has been used for several decades, new catalyst formulations, as well as more advanced characterization techniques suitable for analysis under reaction conditions, present an opportunity to obtain a more detailed understanding of the catalytic mechanism, and thereby further develop the catalyst technology. The techniques developed as part of the project will be broadly applicable to a range of catalytic processes - especially those carried out in liquids. The principal investigator will also integrate international research opportunities and research opportunities targeting underrepresented groups into the project.

The project will examine the surface chemistry involved in the hydrogenation of various dialkyl oxalate species on Cu, Ag, Au-Cu, and Au-Ag catalysts - both supported and unsupported - and both in the gas and liquid phases. Critical to the project will be the implementation of a new attentuated total reflection infrared spectrophotometer (ATR-IR) as the primary tool and through design of a new high-pressure and high-temperature ATR-IR cell. Application of the new ATR-IR cell, together with reaction kinetics obtained under the same conditions, should shed new insight on the catalytic reaction mechanism and factors affecting catalyst stability and poisoning. A unique feature of the study is that experiments will be conducted in both gas phase and liquid phase environments under conditions close to those utilized in industrial practice.

The fundamental nature of the project, involving relatively complex organic chemicals and multiple reaction pathways, as well as reaction in both aqueous and gas phase environments, makes it an important test-bed for the improved experimental capabilities offered by the high pressure/temperature ATR-IR cell. Information derived from the study should offer insight into a broad range of catalytic processes ranging from electrocatalysis to photocatalysis and to catalytic conversion of biomass intermediate products. Catalysis in liquid phase environments will be particularly amenable to study by the tools and techniques demonstrated in this project. The PI will also integrate several novel educational opportunities into the proposed research project, including an international research experience for his graduate students, and research opportunities for underrepresented groups at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ethylene glycol (EG) is an important organic compound and chemical intermediate used in a large number of industrial processes. While EG can be readily produced from petroleum-derived ethylene oxide, there is strong and recent interest in using syngas derived from coal, natural gas, and biomass.  One route to EG production is converting syngas through the use of dialkyl oxalate intermediates produced from CO coupling reactions. These oxalate intermediates can be selectively hydrogenated to produce the desired EG product, as well as valuable products such as methyl glycolate (MG) and ethanol. The overall goal of the proposed research was to explore the catalysis and surface chemistry of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) hydrogenation on Cu and Ag-based catalysts. Emphasis was placed both on new catalyst development and on the in-situ characterization of the catalyst surface through the use of attenuated total reflection infrared spectroscopy (ATR-IR). It was hypothesized that such measurements, when correlated with catalyst structural characterization and reaction kinetics experiments, will provide a deeper, molecular level insight into several mechanistic aspects of these reactions. More specifically, the goals of the proposal were 1) to explore and catalogue the surface species resulting from dimethyl oxalate adsorption and reaction on unsupported and supported metals/promoting oxides, both in the gas and liquid phase using ATR-IR and 2) to correlate surface speciation information with reaction kinetics obtained under the same conditions, with a particular view towards understanding stability and poisoning. Two new classes of Cu-based catalysts were developed and studied for the hydrogenation of DMO: Indium-promoted Cu/SiO2 and Cu/KIT-6.  These catalysts significantly outperform existing Cu catalysts in the literature. In addition, ATR-IR evidence was obtained for molecular adsorption of DMO on both Cu and Ag catalyst surfaces under in-situ conditions (although not under reaction conditions due to experimental limitations).

Two PhD students were educated through this project, as well as two undergraduate students.  One paper has been published with four more in preparation.  The work has been presented at several technical conferences including the American Institute of Chemical Engineers Annual Meeting, the North American Catalysis Society meeting, and the Organic Reactions Catalysis Society meeting.  The research results have been integrated into the core chemical engineering curriculum and joint graduate and undergraduate electives as in-class case studies.
